title: Mount Stephenson
text:
Mount Stephenson a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>. It is located within the central portion of the <a href="Douglas%20Range">Douglas Range</a>, standing at the heads of <a href="Toynbee%20Glacier">Toynbee Glacier</a> and <a href="Sedgwick%20Glacier">Sedgwick Glacier</a> west of <a href="George%20VI%20Sound">George VI Sound</a>, near the east coast of <a href="Alexander%20Island">Alexander Island</a> within the <a href="British%20Antarctic%20Territory">British Antarctic Territory</a>. At an elevation of , Mount Stephenson is the highest mountain in the Douglas Range and the highest point on Alexander Island. <a href="Mount%20Egbert">Mount Egbert</a> ranks second, standing at 2,895 m and lies south-southeast of Mount Stephenson.
The mountain was probably first seen in 1909 by the <a href="French%20Antarctic%20Expedition">French Antarctic Expedition</a> under Charcot, but not recognized as part of the Douglas Range. It was first surveyed in 1936 by Stephenson, Fleming, and Bertram of the <a href="British%20Graham%20Land%20Expedition">British Graham Land Expedition</a> (BGLE) under Rymill. The east side of the mountain was resurveyed in 1948 by the <a href="Falkland%20Islands%20Dependencies%20Survey">Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey</a> (FIDS) who named the feature for <a href="Alfred%20Stephenson">Alfred Stephenson</a>, surveyor and leader of the BGLE party to George VI Sound in 1936. Another landform on Alexander Island happens to be named for Alfred Stephenson, <a href="Stephenson%20Nunatak">Stephenson Nunatak</a>.
